docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Some barriers to health care are found in any voluntary system of coverage, whether or not it is offered through an employer. Others are found in any system that leaves coverage financially out of anyone's reach. And the entire problem is complicated by our society's choosing to treat health care as a matter of insurance and not as a universal entitlement.

headline.main: Revising the Rules Of Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Sidney J Socolar letter on August 19 article holds another barrier to health insurance is belief that health care is matter of insurance and not universal entitlement

docs.lead_paragraph: COOPERATION involving government, banks and nonprofit groups is helping Long Islanders who thought they might not be able buy homes to become homeowners, in some cases with aid payments that more than match the buyers' savings. ''There are a lot of barriers for young people on Long Island wanting to buy a home,'' said Marianne Garvin, executive vice president of the Community Development Corporation of Long Island. ''Besides the high housing costs, they need help with credit and savings. We are also discovering that many people who already own homes are victims of predatory lenders, and that is a real crisis.''

headline.main: In the Region/Long Island; Helping New Buyers Cope With High Housing Costs

docs.abstract: Community Development Corp administers federal home-buying assistance programs on Long Island and provides services and training necessary for clients to purchase and maintain homes they can afford; is chartered to make loans to those who cannot obtain them through traditional means; recently opened full-service home ownership center in Centereach; photo (In the Region/Long Island) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kristine Evelyne Sockwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Sockwell Jr. of Washington, was married yesterday to Kevin Jerel Friend, the son of Dr. Beverly Friend-Mayfield of Cincinnati and Augusta, Ga. The Rev. Marilyn Newhouse performed the ceremony at the Calvary United Methodist Church in Annapolis, Md. The bride, 26, is a consultant at Stromberg Consulting, a management consulting company in New York that works on management issues. She graduated from Spelman College and received a master's degree in organizational psychology from Columbia. Her father, who is retired, was the founder and chief executive of the Construction Loan Insurance Corporation, a municipal bond insurance company that was in Washington. He is now an executive in residence at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business. Her mother, Harriet Sockwell, is an educational consultant with the ''I Have a Dream'' Foundation in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: LET'S say you are a buying a home and let's say, despite the current seller's market, you find a house that you truly love and can afford. The inspector you hire reports the house is perfect. Your hand is hovering over the dotted line. And then suddenly . . . Fear paralyzes you at the mention of a dark presence beneath the property. It's an oil tank.

headline.main: In the Region/New Jersey; When Buying a House, Beware the Buried Oil Tank

docs.abstract: New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection oversees about 1,800 residential oil tank cleanups annually; larger commercial tanks must be registered and inspected annually, but residential tanks of less than 1,100 gallons are exempt from this requirement; buyers of homes should take measures to avoid liability for any leaks and cleanup costs; photo (In the Region/New Jersey) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: TALK about shark season. Congress came back into session last week and the Democrats were circling, sensing blood in the political waters. The Republicans had an air of panic. Only last spring, the Democrats were unable to stop President Bush's $1.35 trillion, ten-year tax cut. But with the economy slowing, the budget surplus shrinking and President Bush in danger of having to break his pledge not to dip into the Social Security surplus, Democrats have returned to Washington crowing, ''I told you so.''

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Face Off; Which Way to Win Control of Congress?

docs.abstract: Democrats are hoping to seize initiative in 2002 Congressional elections by forcing Bush administration to submit new budget that reflects economic slowdown and evaporation of projected budget surplus; their best hope may be to convince public that party must take control of Congress to keep Pres Bush to his pledge to preserve Social Security surplus exclusively for Social Security; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A One-Time Adjustment For Changing Tastes Young consumers can be a fickle bunch, and few may know that better than the Sharper Image Corporation.
docs.abstract: Sharper Image reported last week that same-store sales, those at stores open at least one year, declined 32 percent in August from same period year ago, while total company sales fell 23 percent; Walt Disney Co has revamped eight-minute Jungle Cruise ride at its Disneyland theme park in Anaheim, Calif, so that it no longer includes shots fired at mechanical hippopotamuses; change was made in response to comments from patrons; Kaiser Family Foundation survey shows premiums for employer-sponsored health insurance rose 11 percent this year, on average; finds average annual premium shared by employers and employees was $2,650 for single coverage and $7,053 for family coverage (M)
docs.snippet: A One-Time Adjustment For Changing Tastes      Young consumers can be a fickle bunch, and few may know that better than the Sharper Image Corporation.

docs.lead_paragraph: She picked at her head until she scratched bald spots on her scalp. Her blackest depressions left her mute and catatonic, unable to recognize any semblance of hope. She tried to commit suicide in June 1999 and berated herself for failing. She thought, as a nurse, she should at least know how to kill herself. And barely a month after that first suicide attempt, Andrea Yates tried to slash her own throat before her husband grabbed the knife.

headline.main: Despair Plagued Mother Held in Children's Deaths

docs.abstract: Andrea Yates, Texas mother charged with drowning her five children, is described in medical records filed in court as severely depressed and psychotic, mute, catatonic and suicidal, with record of hospitalization; photo; she is described as shy, without self-esteem and overwhelmed by child-rearing and home schooling, telling therapist that her husband allowed her two hours of personal time a week; two suicide attempts followed birth of fourth children; psychiatrist warned that couple's determination to 'have as many babies as nature would allow' guaranteed psychosis and depression (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Swiss Reinsurance Company reported its first-half profit plunged 55 percent, to $800 million, as the reinsurer, the world's second largest, experienced a steep drop in its earnings from buying and selling securities. This compared with $1.8 billion in the period last year. The Zurich company, however, had a 43 percent rise in operating profit from other units, including health and life insurance. Swiss Re, which assumes insurers' risks for disasters, is expected to sell some $2.6 billion in new shares to help pay for the purchase of the reinsurance unit of Lincoln National in Philadelphia. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

headline.main: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Reinsurer's Profit Falls

docs.abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Co reports that its first-half profit plunged 55 percent, to $800 million, due to steep drop in earnings from securities trading (S)
